body:
Comment 4 by **gorgonzola@online.de**: 
my 2 cent are that consistency in writing a slice notation helps beginners. because a
slice notation is not really something a developer is 'testing thoroughly' but rather
something that he uses intuitively (or by experience from other languages), he is
most probably at trying to find out something else when the compiler barks about
wrong slice notation. he has to stop what he wanted to test and learn to understand
slicing first. you might find this correct, but if the language disrupts that easily,
'checking it out' can become annoying (same with semicolons!) this is why i would go
with consistency. because the [:] notation does no harm but allows a beginner to go
on and learn later about the 'better' syntax, i would vote for it.

p.s.: python supports negative slicing. somebody might try this too with go and see
that it doesn't work. however, he will immediately understand, i believe. if he can't
do [:], though he can do [0:], he will probably first find this strange and 'awkward'
and post his findings to the list, as happened. i can understand him.
